facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1071 of 1966 filed by special leave in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION-Civil Appeal No. 1071 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 10,

facts.text: Appeal from Award dated September 10, 1965 of Labour Court, Jullundur in Reference No. 157 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 10, 1965, of the Labour Court, Jullundur in Reference No. 157 of 1959. B. Sinha, and B. P. Maheshwari, for the appellant Hardev Singh, for respondents Nos. 2 to 24.

facts.text: Reference No. 150 of 1958 pending regarding industrial dispute on bonus, casual leave, sick leave between appellant and workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Jaganmohan Reddy, J While reference No 150 of 1958 was pending in respect of an Industrial dispute between the appellant and its workmen relating to bonus, casual leave and sick leave etc., and. after the management had suspended six of its workmen on certain charges of misconduct for having refused to ,operate some machines,

facts.text: Management suspended six workmen on charges of misconduct for refusing to operate machines.

anchor.surface_text: and. after the management had suspended six of its workmen on certain charges of misconduct for having refused to ,operate some machines, another worker Shri Darshan Singh, a Helper of a Blowing Machine also refused on 25-1-59 when called upon by the management to work the machine in tile absence ,of Shri Daulat Ram, Machineman and was accordingly suspended the same day.

facts.text: Shri Darshan Singh, Helper of Blowing Machine, refused to work on 25-1-59, suspended same day.

anchor.surface_text: another worker Shri Darshan Singh, a Helper of a Blowing Machine also refused on 25-1-59 when called upon by the management to work the machine in tile absence ,of Shri Daulat Ram, Machineman and was accordingly suspended the same day. On hearing this news the workmen went to see one of the partners of the appellant and demanded that the order of suspension passed against Shri Darshan Singh should be cancelled and he be reinstated as a Helper.

facts.text: Workmen demanded cancellation of suspension of Darshan Singh and his reinstatement; management not agreeable, leading to lightning strike.

anchor.surface_text: On hearing this news the workmen went to see one of the partners of the appellant and demanded that the order of suspension passed against Shri Darshan Singh should be cancelled and he be reinstated as a Helper. As the management was number agreeable to reinstate the Helper workman, the workers went on a lightening strike.

facts.text: Respondents 2 to 24 went on strike on 25-1-59.

anchor.surface_text: that the Respondents went on a strike on 25-1-59  2  that as there was a reference pending before the Labour Court that strike would be illegal, under Chapter V of the Industrial Disputes Act 1947  3  that both the Labour Officers as well as the management tried to persuade the workers to join duty

facts.text: Conciliation efforts by Labour Officer (MW2), Labour Inspector (MW4), management failed; respondents did not report for duty.

anchor.surface_text: Since the workmen came on strike company- ciliation efforts were made but in spite of the persuasion of the Labour Officer, M.W. 2, the Labour Inspector M.W. 4 and by the management, Respondents 2 to 24 along with other did number report for duty although it is stated the Appellant was willing to employ them. Certain charge-sheets were served on the working on towards the end of January to which replies were given.

facts.text: Charge-sheets served on workers end of January 1959; replies given.

anchor.surface_text: Certain charge-sheets were served on the working on towards the end of January to which replies were given. Thereafter numberices were sent to the Respondents 2 to 15 and 17 to 24 asking them to resume work by certain specified dates and when they did number resume work other numberices were sent requiring the said Respondents to show why their names should number be struck,off and asked them to submit their reply by a certain date.

facts.text: Notices sent to Respondents 2-15,17-24 to resume work by specified dates; no compliance.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter numberices were sent to the Respondents 2 to 15 and 17 to 24 asking them to resume work by certain specified dates and when they did number resume work other numberices were sent requiring the said Respondents to show why their names should number be struck,off and asked them to submit their reply by a certain date. In so far as Respondent 16 is companycerned a numberice was served oil him ,on 4-3-59 in which it was mentioned that he was absent since 13-2-59 without any leave and that he should resume duty by 6-3-59.

facts.text: Respondent 16 (Surat Singh) notice on 4-3-59 for absence since 13-2-59 without leave; to resume by 6-3-59, explain by 8-3-59.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as Respondent 16 is companycerned a numberice was served oil him ,on 4-3-59 in which it was mentioned that he was absent since 13-2-59 without any leave and that he should resume duty by 6-3-59. He was further asked to explain by 8-3-59 why his name should number be struck off. None of the Respondents Nos. 2 to 24 either acknowledged these numberices number sent a reply.

facts.text: None of Respondents 2-24 acknowledged notices or replied.

anchor.surface_text: None of the Respondents Nos. 2 to 24 either acknowledged these numberices number sent a reply. The management thereafter by letters dated 23-2-59, 4-3-59 and 17-3-59 informed the aforesaid Respondents that since they were numberlonger interested in the employment their names were struck off from the muster rolls.

facts.text: Management struck off names of Respondents from muster rolls by letters dated 23-2-59, 4-3-59, 17-3-59.

anchor.surface_text: The management thereafter by letters dated 23-2-59, 4-3-59 and 17-3-59 informed the aforesaid Respondents that since they were numberlonger interested in the employment their names were struck off from the muster rolls. It is alleged that from 25-1-59 till their names were struck off from the muster rolls, the Respondents sat outside the Mill gate

facts.text: From 25-1-59 to striking off, Respondents sat outside Mill gate despite persuasion.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that from 25-1-59 till their names were struck off from the muster rolls, the Respondents sat outside the Mill gate and in spite of persuasion by the Labour Officer as well as by the management were genuinely desirous of their resuming work, they did number join duty and as a companysequence the management was companypelled to employ others in order to keep the mill going.

facts.text: Management employed others to keep mill going; some workmen who wanted joined duty.

anchor.surface_text: they did number join duty and as a companysequence the management was companypelled to employ others in order to keep the mill going. It is also stated that during this period those workmen who wanted to join duty were permitted to do so and their services were entertained. It is also the case of the management that the strike fizzled out after the striking-workmen failed to get rations and thereafter they had abandoned the service.

facts.text: Demand notice on 19-3-59 by workmen; conciliation commenced.

anchor.surface_text: On 19-3-59 a demand numberice on behalf of the workmen was served on the management as a result of which the companyciliation proceedings companymenced. But even then according to the report of the Conciliation Officer while the management was willing to employ the workmen, the Respondents were, number willing to resume work till the suspended workmen were also allowed to resume duty.

facts.text: Matter referred to Labour Court Jullundur on 26-8-59 under Sec. 10 ID Act for 31 workmen termination.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately on 26-8-59 the matter was referred to the Labour Court at Jullundur under Sec. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act , to determine whether the termination of services of 31 workmen whose names were mentioned therein was justified. It may be mentioned here that out of these 31 workmen 8 workmen had resumed their duties and were numberlonger interested in the proceedings.

facts.text: Labour Court award on 31-10-61 rejecting workmen claim; published 8-12-61.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court after receiving the statement of claim and recording the evidence on behalf of both the management and the workmen. passed an Award on 31-10-61 which was published in the Gazette of 8-12-61. By this Award the claim of the workmen was rejected on the ground inter-alia -  a  that they had resorted to illegal strike  b  that the management did number in fact terminate the services of the workmen companycerned in the case

facts.text: Punjab High Court single bench judgment 6-12-64 remanded case to Labour Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against this Award of the Labour Court a Writ Petition was filed by the Respondents in the High Court of Punjab. A Single Bench of that Court by its Judgment dated 6-12-64 held that in law the plea that the workers had abandoned the services of the Appellant companyld number be sustained, but on the other hand it was the management which had terminated their services. In this view the case was remanded to the Labour Court for a fresh decision.

facts.text: Labour Court remand award 10-9-65 directed reinstatement of Respondents 2-24; published 1-10-65.

anchor.surface_text: On remand the Labour Court by an Award dated 10-9-65 which was published in the Gazette on 1-10-65 held that the plea of the -L 1340 Sup CI/71 workmen that there was a lock out by the management was number substantiated, on the other hand it was they who had gone on strike that the strike was illegal

facts.text: No standing orders applicable to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as Surat Singh Respondent No. 16 was companycerned, it was found that there were numberstanding orders in force applicable to the Appellant, as such it was number justified in dismissing him for absence without leave.

facts.text: Strike illegal due to pending Reference No. 150/1958.

facts.text: Management and Labour Officers persuaded workers to resume duty; workers conditioned on suspended workmen reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: 3  that both the Labour Officers as well as the management tried to persuade the workers to join duty and after the demand numberice dated 19-3-59 companyciliation efforts were made but they did number resume work and made it a companydition of their joining duty that the suspended workmen also should be taken back  4  that the management gave workers on strike numberices on different dates

facts.text: No domestic enquiry held into misconduct of respondents.

anchor.surface_text: 6  that numberdomestic enquiry was held into the misconduct of the Respondents. On these admitted facts it is sought to be companytended on behalf of the Appellant that the Management took every possible step to get the workmen back into their factory but they were adamant in companytinuing the strike.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds termination justified except for Respondent 16 Surat Singh.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we take the order terminating their services was number improper. The Tribunal was number justified in directing their reinstatement and payment of wages merely on the round that numberdomestic enquiry was held. The appeal is accordingly allowed except for the Award in respect of Surat Singh, which is maintained.

holdings.text: The order terminating the services of Respondents Nos. 2 to 24 (except Respondent No. 16) was not improper and the Tribunal was not justified in directing their reinstatement merely because no domestic enquiry was held.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we take the order terminating their services was number improper. The Tribunal was number justified in directing their reinstatement and payment of wages merely on the round that numberdomestic enquiry was held. The appeal is accordingly allowed except for the Award in respect of Surat Singh, which is maintained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Management proved misconduct of persistent refusal to resume duty on merits before Tribunal despite no prior enquiry; supported by precedents like Punjab National Bank and Motipur Sugar Factory allowing justification on evidence.

holdings.text: Termination of services of Shri Surat Singh (Respondent No. 16) is not valid due to absence of standing orders applicable to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that it has been companyceded at the very outset that there being number,standing orders applicable to the Appellant, the termination of the services of Shri Surat Singh, Respondent No. 16 is number valid and the Award pertaining to his reinstatement cannot be assailed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded by parties; no standing orders permit dismissal for absence without leave.

holdings.text: Persistent and obdurate refusal by workmen to join duty, despite management's persuasion and opportunities offered, constitutes misconduct justifying termination of services.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied undisputed facts of illegal strike, notices to resume, no replies, conditional refusal; misconduct proved without need for violence.

holdings.text: Proof of overt acts such as intimidation, incitement or violence is not a necessary prerequisite in every case to justify termination for misconduct during an illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that in every case the proof of such overt acts are necessary prerequisite.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent's contention; sufficient here is obdurate refusal based on evidence and precedents.

holdings.text: Even where no domestic enquiry is held prior to termination for misconduct (including during illegal strike), the management can justify the order before the Tribunal by adducing evidence to prove the misconduct on merits.

anchor.surface_text: If however the management does number hold such an enquiry or the enquiry is due to some omission or deficiency number valid it can numberetheless support its order of discharge, termination

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents (Punjab National Bank, Motipur Sugar Factory, Express Newspapers); Tribunal adjudicates merits under Sec. 10 ID Act; lower threshold of proof than criminal court.

holdings.text: The strike on 25-1-59 was illegal under Chapter V of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, due to pendency of Reference No. 150 of 1958 before the Labour Court.

The workers moved the High Court under Art. 226

precedents.cited_proposition: Even where the strike is illegal, the employer can take disciplinary action against the employees under the Standing Orders after domestic enquiry

Their Workmen 1 where it was held that mere taking part in an illegal strike without anything further would number necessarily justify the dismissal of all the workers taking part in the strike and that if the employer, before dismissing a workman, gives him sufficient opportunity

precedents.case_name: India General Navigation & Railway Co Ltd v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Mere participation in an illegal strike does not justify dismissal without giving the workman opportunity to explain conduct
precedents.cited_holding: mere taking part in an illegal strike without anything further would number necessarily justify the dismissal of all the workers taking part in the strike

precedents.citation: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Its Workmen

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant before us on the evidence produced before the Tribunal seeks to justify its order removing the names of the Respondents from the muster roll. In the Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Its Workmen, 2 though there was numberenquiry held by the management it sought to justify the action of termination of services of its employees before the Industrial Tribunal. The employees of the Appellant Bank had companymenced pen down strikes which were followed by general strike Pending arbitration of an industrial dispute between them.

precedents.case_name: Punjab National Bank Ltd v Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Management can justify termination of services before the Industrial Tribunal even if no prior enquiry was held
precedents.cited_holding: under Sec. 33A of the Act ... the employer could still justify the impugned dismissal on merits

precedents.citation: Workmen of Motipur Sugar Factory P Ltd., v. Motipur Sugar Factory

anchor.surface_text: In Workmen of Motipur Sugar Factory P Ltd., v. Motipur Sugar Factory, 1 the workers of the Respondent started a go slow in its Sugar Factory. Therefore the Respondent issued a general numberice to those workmen and individually to each workman numberifying-that unless he recorded his willingness to discharge his duties faithfully and diligently so as to give a certain minimum output, he will be numberlonger employed and the willingness he was required to record was to be done within a certain time failing which he was numberified that he would be discharged without further numberice.

precedents.case_name: Workmen of Motipur Sugar Factory Pvt Ltd v Motipur Sugar Factory
precedents.cited_proposition: Discharge can be justified before Tribunal by proving misconduct even if no domestic enquiry held
precedents.cited_holding: the Tribunal may give an opportunity to the employer to prove his case and in doing so the Tribunal tries the merits itself

precedents.citation: Hindustan General Electrical Corporation Ltd. v. Bishwanath Prasad Anr.

anchor.surface_text: In a recent case-the Hindustan General Electrical Corporation Ltd. v. Bishwanath Prasad Anr., 1 while companysidering this aspect of the matter we had held that even though numberenquiry was held or there was companytravention of the provisions of Sec. 33 ,of the Act, in a dispute referred under Sec. 10 the Labour Court had to adjudicate upon the dispute which was referred to it with regard to the Respondent and had to go into the question

precedents.case_name: Hindustan General Electrical Corporation Ltd v Bishwanath Prasad & Anr
precedents.cited_proposition: In a reference under Sec. 10, management can justify dismissal on merits before the Labour Court even without prior enquiry
precedents.cited_holding: the management can justify and substantiate its action on evidence duly placed before the Tribunal
